text: So again, what is to go, to go in French?
Aller.
And you, formal go?
Vous allez.
We go.
Nous allons.
So, these are the parts of to go which all start with an A.
However, as I've mentioned earlier, to go in French is very irregular and unusual.
So there is this A part, but there's also a V part, where all of it begins with V.
For instance, what is I go or I'm going to?
Je vais.
I'm going to eat.
Je vais manger.
How about he goes or he is going?
Il va.
Again, it's not il va, as you might expect it to be, because it's too irregular for that.
So again, what is he goes or he is going?
Il va.
She goes or she is going?
Elle va.
You, informal, are going.
Tu va.
Finally, another V one, but slightly different, how would you say they are going?
Ils vont.
And they, an entirely female group, are going?
Elles vont.
So, let's try with a male group or a mixed group.
They are going to see it.
They are going to see it.
They are going to see it.
They are going to see her.
They are going to see her.
Ils vont.
They are going to see it.
They are going to see it.
They are going to see it.
for it in French which is le, le, can actually be used for both it and him. So if we wanted
to say they're going to see it, we would say, ils vont le voir. And it's going to be the
same if we want to say they're going to see him. How would you say that?
So it can be used for both in French. Sometimes it may be a little unclear but normally the
context should make it obvious what is meant. However, it's important to distinguish very
clearly the sounds between going to see him or it. Again, how would you say they are going
to see it or they're going to see him?
And they're going to see her.
Many students, when pronouncing it, which correctly pronounced is le, may say something
more like les. Perhaps they've picked it up from another language or it simply seems easier
to say. However, you need to be very clear on it. So again, listen to the word for it which
is le, le, le. It almost sounds like the letter L as it's often pronounced when it's taught
to children as a sort of le sound and certainly very distinctly not a lay. So again, it in French
will be le and her will be la. So one more time, let's have an all-female group. They are going
to see it. They are going to see it. They are going to see her. They are going to see her.
They are going to see her. So there we have them. It and her or him and her which again are
le and la. So again, to go is
aller. You, formal, are going. Vous allez. We go, we are going. Nous allons. And now over to the V forms.
I go, I am going. Je vais. He goes, he is going. Il va. She goes, she is going. Elle va.
You, informal, are going. Tu vas. And finally, they are going. Ils vont. They, an all-female group,
are going. Elles vont.
Thank you.
